newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Mandela's island prison to be freedom museum.
newsitem.headline: Mandela's island prison to be freedom museum.

text.p: President Nelson Mandela's cabinet decided on Wednesday that Robben Island, the sandstone prison where he spent 18 of his 27 years in jail, should become a Museum of the Freedom Struggle of South Africa.
The cabinet approved recommendations by Mandela's friend and fellow island inmate, Ahmed Kathrada, for the future of the flat, sandy island in Cape Town's Table Bay.

Robben Island, 11 km (seven miles) long and up to five km (three miles) wide, has served as a lunatic asylum, leper colony and prison throughout the 340 years since European settlers arrived at the Cape.
One prisoner disappeared on a surf-ski stolen from the home of a warder, but there was never a confirmed successful escape from the high-security prison complex near the small harbour.

"Robben Island should be developed as a World Heritage Site, National Monument and National Museum which can become a cultural and conservation showcase for the new South African democracy," the cabinet said in a statement.
The development should enhance the economic, tourism and educational potential of the island without allowing what the cabinet called "crass commercialism".
Proposals for the future of the island have included a casino, a holiday resort and a novelty hotel with Mandela's tiny cell as the prime attraction.

"Robben Island should be run as a site museum, where the total environment is conserved in an integrated way...and the ex-political prison (should) be converted into a Museum of the Freedom Struggle in South Africa," the cabinet said.
The island, named after the Dutch word for seals, also has a thriving colony of endangered jackass penguins.
The proposal by the cabinet, which includes three of Mandela's prison colleagues, calls for him to head a trust that would raise funds and oversee the development of the island.
Prison governor Colonel Elsa Jones told Reuters by telephone that she welcomed the decision to close the prison by the end of 1996 and to develop it as a cultural site, saying:
"I fully agree with the plan, I'm very pleased with it."
Jones said only 113 prisoners were still held on the island, which has held close to 1,000 prisoners at times, mainly to maintain roads, waterworks and the small harbour.
She said 83 staff families remained on the island, which has its own primary school, but would begin to leave later this month as the prison winds down.
The prison service decided not to renovate the maximum- security "B wing" in which Mandela and other African National Congress leaders were held, initially under inhumane conditions.
In his first years after arriving on the island in 1964, Mandela was given only a shirt and short trousers, shoes without socks, two blankets and a mat to sleep on the concrete floor.
Prisoners worked in a lime quarry, which harmed the health of many including Mandela, now 78, who has had eye surgery to partially correct the damage that still causes him pain.
